cheatsheetvideos.quote: David Got help for his Class M using our Cheat sheet!
Jose explains how the motorcycle cheat sheet helped him pass his written exam.

questions.question: If operating a three-wheeled motorcycle or riding with a sidecar, do not ride too far to the right of your lane because:
questions.answerA: Other drivers may not see you.
questions.answerB: You will not be able to pass other vehicles as easily.
questions.answerC: Other drivers may try to share your lane.
questions.answerD: You may run off the road.
questions.explanation: Because a sidecar sits on the right side of a motorcycle, riding too far to the right side of your lane risks the sidecar running off the road. Similarly, on a three-wheeled motorcycle, the rear right wheel may leave the road if you get too close to the right edge.

questions.question: A properly-fitted motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Allows the rider to touch the ground with their feet while seated.
questions.answerB: Has a seat even with the rider's waist.
questions.answerC: Has a seat that is 10 inches above the rider's waist.
questions.answerD: Has a seat that is 10 inches below the rider's waist.
questions.explanation: If your motorcycle fits you properly, your feet should be able to reach the ground while you are seated. When riding your motorcycle, keep your feet firmly on the footrests.

questions.question: The shortest and safest stops are accomplished:
questions.answerA: By using only the rear brake.
questions.answerB: By using only the front brake.
questions.answerC: By allowing the front tire to lock up.
questions.answerD: By using both the front and rear brakes.
questions.explanation: The shortest and safest stops are achieved by using both the front and rear brakes in a smooth and progressive manner, without skidding either tire.

questions.question: If you are transporting a passenger, they should:
questions.answerB: Hold onto the motorcycle seat.
questions.answerC: Sit as far back as possible.
questions.answerD: Never hold onto you.
questions.explanation: A passenger should lean with the operator through turns and curves. They should sit as far forward as possible, without hindering the operator's control of the motorcycle, and hold onto passenger handholds or the operator's waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: Slippery surfaces can make it difficult to control a motorcycle. Which of the following would be considered a slippery surface?
questions.answerB: A driveway
questions.answerC: Dry pavement
questions.answerD: A parking lot
questions.explanation: Wet pavement; roads covered in loose gravel or sand; muddy, snowy, or icy areas; painted lane markings; and metal covers and plates in the road can be slippery surfaces. Motorcyclists should ride with extra caution when riding over slippery surfaces.

questions.question: To be effective, an eye or face shield must:
questions.answerB: Prevent air from passing through.
questions.answerC: Not allow for eyeglasses to fit underneath.
questions.answerD: Restrict your vision to the sides.
questions.explanation: To be effective, an eye or face shield must be free of scratches; be resistant to penetration; allow clear views to both sides; fasten securely; permit air to pass through to prevent fogging; and allow room for eyeglasses or sunglasses, if needed.

questions.question: To increase your visibility, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn off your headlight during the day.
questions.answerB: Wear dark clothes.
questions.answerC: Keep your headlight on at all times.
questions.answerD: Ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: Strategies for making yourself more visible include wearing brightly-colored and reflective clothing, keeping your headlight on at all times, and varying your lane position as conditions demand.

questions.question: Impairment from drinking alcohol occurs:
questions.answerB: Once reaching the legal limit.
questions.answerC: Just above the legal limit.
questions.answerD: Well above the legal limit.
questions.explanation: It is never safe to operate a motorcycle after consuming any amount of alcohol. Impairment of the skills needed to safely ride begins well below the legal limit.

questions.question: A flat front tire is especially hazardous because:
questions.answerB: The front tire provides the power for the bike, so you will lose acceleration.
questions.answerC: The flat tire will shake the bike, making it hard to use the mirrors.
questions.answerD: You won’t be able to use the brake.
questions.explanation: A flat front tire is especially dangerous because it affects your ability to steer. If your front tire goes flat while you are riding, safely exit the road as quickly as possible.

questions.question: A simple way to make your motorcycle easier to see is to:
questions.answerA: Ride with a large flag attached to its frame.
questions.answerB: Ride with the headlight turned on.
questions.answerC: Wave at other drivers.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder whenever possible.
questions.explanation: You can make yourself easier to see by wearing brightly-colored, reflective clothing. Ride with your headlight on at all times and use your turn signals and brake light appropriately.

questions.question: Motorcyclists riding in a group should avoid pairing up because:
questions.answerA: A merging driver may not see both riders.
questions.answerB: Reflections from both helmets may make it difficult for the riders to see.
questions.answerC: Riding in pairs does not allow riders the necessary space to maneuver.
questions.answerD: It is too difficult for riders on the left side of a pairing to exit a highway.
questions.explanation: When traveling in a group, it is never recommended for motorcyclists to ride in pairs. Neither rider will have adequate room to maneuver to avoid hazards.

questions.question: When should the front brake be used?
questions.answerA: Any time the rider is slowing or stopping
questions.answerB: Only when slowing or stopping on slippery roads
questions.answerC: Only when slowing or stopping in an emergency
questions.answerD: Only when slowing or stopping in traffic
questions.explanation: A rider should always use both brakes every time they slow or stop.

questions.question: When you ride a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head and shoulders to look through turns.
questions.answerB: Keep your arms straight.
questions.answerC: Keep your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerD: Turn just your head and eyes to look through turns.
questions.explanation: When turning, look through the turn to where you want to go by turning only your head. Keep your knees against the gas tank to help maintain your balance while turning. Your arms should be slightly bent any time you are holding the handgrips.

questions.question: When conducting a pre-ride check, be sure that:
questions.answerA: The brakes make a loud squeaking noise.
questions.answerB: The brakes cause some friction with the steering.
questions.answerC: Each brake can hold the motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Only the rear brake can hold the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Check your brake levers individually before every ride. Make sure each one feels firm and holds the motorcycle when the brake is fully applied.

questions.question: If you think stopping your motorcycle will take longer than usual, you should:
questions.answerB: Shorten your following distance.
questions.answerC: Leave the road.
questions.answerD: Speed up.
questions.explanation: Lengthen your following distance when traveling on a slippery surface. If it will take longer than usual for your motorcycle to stop, open up to a longer following distance.

questions.question: When riding at night, you should:
questions.answerA: Be flexible about your lane position and adjust to changing conditions.
questions.answerB: Travel at a faster speed than usual to get to your destination more quickly.
questions.answerC: Always use your low beam headlight to see better.
questions.answerD: Decrease your following distance so you can be as close as possible to the vehicle ahead.
questions.explanation: Always be flexible about your lane position, especially when riding at night. Be especially careful to employ safe riding strategies when riding under conditions that are less than ideal.

questions.question: When entering a turn, a rider should:
questions.answerB: Reduce their speed.
questions.answerC: Move their shoulders to match the angle of the turn.
questions.answerD: Sit up as high as possible.
questions.explanation: Before entering a turn, a motorcyclist should reduce their speed by closing the throttle and, if necessary, applying both brakes.

questions.question: If another driver is following you too closely, it is best to:
questions.answerB: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.answerC: Speed up.
questions.answerD: Get off the roadway.
questions.explanation: The best way to deal with a tailgater is to get them in front of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let them pass. Increasing your speed may only encourage the driver to tailgate you at a higher speed.

questions.question: Which formation is best for a group of riders entering a curve?
questions.answerB: Staggered
questions.answerC: Single-file
questions.answerD: Compressed
questions.explanation: A staggered formation is generally the best way for a group to maintain close ranks while also allowing each rider to maintain an adequate cushion of space. A single-file formation is preferable when taking curves, turning, or entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: Which of the following should you inspect during a pre-ride check?
questions.answerA: The general wear and tread of your tires
questions.answerB: The amount of cushion your seat has
questions.answerC: The shine of your paint
questions.answerD: The wind direction
questions.explanation: Before setting off on any ride, you should do a thorough check of your motorcycle. Inspect the tires, oil and fluid levels, headlight, tail light, turn signals, brake light, clutch and throttle, mirrors, brakes, and horn.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield:
questions.answerA: Is not necessary if you have a windshield.
questions.answerB: Only protects your eyes.
questions.answerC: Protects more than just your eyes.
questions.answerD: Does not protect your face as well as goggles.
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield helps protect your entire face, including your eyes. Goggles can protect your eyes, but not the rest of your face. A windshield is not an adequate substitute for either.

questions.question: If you must ride over an obstacle, you should:
questions.answerA: Decrease your speed as much as possible.
questions.answerB: Lean the motorcycle to one side.
questions.answerC: Speed up, if possible.
questions.answerD: Stay on your seat and remove your feet from the footrests.
questions.explanation: If you are unable avoid an obstacle and must instead ride over it, slow down and approach the obstacle at as close to a 90-degree angle as possible. Keep your motorcycle straight up and down, if possible. Just before contact, roll off the throttle slightly to lighten the front end of the motorcycle.

questions.question: A wobble, or shaking of the front wheel and handlebars, may be caused by:
questions.answerB: Brakes that are not working properly.
questions.answerC: A balanced load.
questions.answerD: Excessive wind.
questions.explanation: Most wobbles are caused by improper loading of the motorcycle, unsuitable accessories, or incorrect tire pressure.

questions.question: A pre-ride inspection usually takes:
questions.answerA: A few minutes and should be done no more than once a month.
questions.answerB: A few minutes and should be done before every ride.
questions.answerC: Over an hour and should be performed by a mechanic.
questions.answerD: Over an hour and must only be done if you will be carrying a passenger.
questions.explanation: Conduct a thorough pre-ride inspection before every ride. It should usually take only a few minutes.

questions.question: The right clothing:
questions.answerA: Protects a rider in a collision.
questions.answerB: Makes a rider look cool.
questions.answerC: Should be more stylish than protective.
questions.answerD: Should be loose-fitting.
questions.explanation: Properly chosen clothing will help to protect a rider in the event of a collision. It should be made of sturdy, brightly-colored, and reflective materials. When riding, clothes should fit snugly enough that they do not flap in the wind, but loosely enough that they allow the motorcyclist to move freely.

questions.question: Usually, a minimum following distance of _____ should be maintained.
questions.answerB: Two seconds
questions.answerC: Three seconds
questions.answerD: Four seconds
questions.explanation: Generally, you should maintain a minimum following distance of two seconds. Increase your following distance to at least three seconds whenever you are riding under conditions that are less than ideal.

questions.question: To prevent getting fatigued on a long ride, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Limit the distance traveled in a day.
questions.answerC: Take frequent rest breaks.
questions.answerD: Take artificial stimulants.
questions.explanation: To reduce the danger of fatigue when riding, dress to protect yourself against tiring weather conditions, such as wind and rain. Limit yourself to no more than about six hours of riding per day and stop for a break at least once every two hours. Avoid taking artificial stimulants since you may experience extreme fatigue when they start to wear off.

questions.question: You will ______ hear a tire going flat.
questions.answerB: Usually
questions.answerC: Frequently
questions.answerD: Seldom
questions.explanation: Motorcycle riders will rarely actually hear a tire going flat. Tire failure is more often indicated by a change in how the motorcycle handles.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger, you should tell them to do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Get on the motorcycle after the engine has been started.
questions.answerB: Sit as far forward as they can without crowding you.
questions.answerC: Hold firmly onto your waist, hips, or belt.
questions.answerD: Feel free to talk whenever they want.
questions.explanation: To help keep the operator focused on riding, passengers should avoid unnecessary conversation or movement. Passengers should get on a motorcycle only after the engine has been started. They should sit as far forward as they can without crowding the operator and hold firmly onto the operator's waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: Intersections are usually:
questions.answerA: Safe since there is so much traffic there.
questions.answerB: A dangerous spot for riders.
questions.answerC: Difficult to figure out.
questions.answerD: Safer than the open road.
questions.explanation: Intersections can be dangerous because they present the greatest degree of potential conflict between motorcyclists and other drivers.

questions.question: A skidding rear tire:
questions.answerB: Eliminates your ability to change direction.
questions.answerC: Will usually correct itself.
questions.answerD: Is only a concern if the front tire is also skidding.
questions.explanation: A skidding rear tire is a dangerous condition that can result in a violent crash and serious injury or death. Too much rear brake pressure can cause the rear wheel to lock. As soon as the rear wheel locks, your ability to change direction is lost. To regain control, the brake must be released.

questions.question: If you must brake and swerve to avoid a hazard, you should:
questions.answerA: Either brake then swerve or swerve then brake.
questions.answerB: Brake and swerve at the same time.
questions.answerC: Choose to either brake or swerve.
questions.answerD: Not swerve and only use the front brake to stop.
questions.explanation: If a hazard requires you to brake and swerve to avoid a collision, you should take the actions separately. Do not brake while swerving because doing so may cause your motorcycle to fall over.

questions.question: When passing a row of parked cars on your right, you should usually:
questions.answerA: Stay in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Stay toward the left side of the lane.
questions.answerC: Not be concerned with the vehicles, since they are parked.
questions.answerD: Look at the left edge of the lane.
questions.explanation: When passing parked cars on your right, it is usually safest to ride in the left portion of your lane. This will keep you away from hazards like doors opening, people stepping out from between cars, and cars pulling out from parking spaces. Always be prepared to adjust your lane positioning for changing road and traffic conditions.

questions.question: If you find yourself riding alongside another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerB: Wave at the other driver.
questions.answerC: Stay alongside the vehicle until the next exit and then exit.
questions.answerD: Let the other driver worry about it.
questions.explanation: Riding directly next to another vehicle is dangerous because you could be riding in the vehicle's blind spot. Additionally, the vehicle may block your route of escape if another hazard arises. If you find yourself riding directly alongside another vehicle, either speed up or drop back.

questions.question: When being passed from behind, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay in the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Stay in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Move onto the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Activate your turn signal.
questions.explanation: When you are being passed from behind or by an oncoming vehicle, stay in the center portion of your lane. Riding any closer to the passing vehicle can put you in danger.

questions.question: To be effective, a face shield should not:
questions.answerB: Allow clear views to both sides.
questions.answerC: Be airtight.
questions.answerD: Fasten securely.
questions.explanation: An effective face shield should be free of scratches, be resistant to penetration, allow clear views to both sides, fasten securely, permit air to pass through, and provide enough space for eyeglasses or sunglasses to be worn underneath. It is important for a face shield to permit the passage of air because an airtight face shield can create fogging and make it difficult for a rider to see.

questions.question: Most motorcycles have rounded, or convex, mirrors. These mirrors:
questions.answerA: Are easy to get used to right away.
questions.answerB: Make cars seem closer than they actually are.
questions.answerC: Provide a narrow view of the road.
questions.answerD: Make cars seem farther away than they actually are.
questions.explanation: In comparison to flat mirrors, convex mirrors provide a wider view of the road behind you. They also make objects seem farther away than they actually are. You should practice judging distances in convex mirrors if you are not used to them.

questions.question: When it comes to motorcycle safety, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume everything on your motorcycle will work properly.
questions.answerB: Conduct a pre-ride inspection before every ride.
questions.answerC: Conduct a pre-ride inspection each month.
questions.answerD: Conduct a pre-ride inspection twice a week.
questions.explanation: A small mechanical fault can have more serious consequences on a motorcycle than on a car. Conduct a thorough pre-ride inspection of your motorcycle before every ride.

questions.question: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should position themselves:
questions.answerB: In the front of the group.
questions.answerC: At the tail end of the group.
questions.answerD: Beside the lead rider.
questions.explanation: Inexperienced riders should ride just behind the leader. This ensures that they won't have to chase after the group, and it allows more experienced riders to keep an eye on them from behind.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a possible cause of a wobble on your motorcycle?
questions.answerB: Improper loading
questions.answerC: Unsuitable accessories
questions.answerD: Uneven road
questions.explanation: Most wobbles can be traced to improper loading, unsuitable accessories, or incorrect tire pressure. Do not try to accelerate out of a wobble.

questions.question: Reflective clothing should:
questions.answerB: Not be worn during the day
questions.answerC: Never be worn.
questions.answerD: Not be worn at night.
questions.explanation: Wear reflective materials to increase your visibility, especially when riding at night. Brightly-colored clothing with reflective materials will make you more visible to other road users.

questions.question: You have been drinking alcohol. If you wait an hour for each drink before riding your motorcycle:
questions.answerA: You cannot be arrested for drinking and riding.
questions.answerB: Your riding skills will not be affected.
questions.answerC: Side effects from the drinking may still remain.
questions.answerD: You will be okay as long as you ride slowly.
questions.explanation: On average, the body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour. However, some alcohol may accumulate in the body even if a person consumes only one drink per hour. Their abilities and judgment can still be impaired.

questions.question: When riding at night, a motorcyclist should maintain a minimum following distance of:
questions.answerB: Three seconds.
questions.answerC: Four seconds.
questions.answerD: Five seconds.
questions.explanation: Because it is more difficult to see and judge distances in the dark than in daylight, you should maintain an expanded following distance of at least three seconds when riding at night. It may take you longer than usual to realize the vehicle in front of you has stopped and you may need additional time to slow or stop to avoid hitting the vehicle.

questions.question: A pre-ride inspection should be done:
questions.answerB: Once a week.
questions.answerC: Once a month.
questions.answerD: Once a season.
questions.explanation: To prevent any dangerous situations caused by technical issues, you should perform a thorough inspection of your motorcycle before every ride. Compared to a car, small technical problems can have more serious consequences on a motorcycle.

questions.question: A DOT-approved helmet:
questions.answerA: Restricts the wearer's vision to the sides.
questions.answerB: Can greatly reduce the severity of a head injury.
questions.answerC: Is usually uncomfortable.
questions.answerD: Makes it more difficult for the wearer to control their motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Wearing a helmet while riding greatly improves your chances of avoiding serious injury to your head or neck in the case of a crash. A DOT-approved helmet will not restrict your vision to the sides.

questions.question: Which type of sign is yellow with black lettering or symbols?
questions.answerB: Service
questions.answerC: Regulatory
questions.answerD: Speed limit
questions.explanation: Warning signs are yellow with black lettering or symbols and provide important information to motorists about upcoming road conditions.

questions.question: If braking in a curve:
questions.answerB: It will be the same as braking on a straightaway.
questions.answerC: You will have more traction as you lean into the curve.
questions.answerD: You may have less traction as you lean into the curve.
questions.explanation: It is possible to use both brakes while turning, but it must be done with great care. Some of the tires' usual traction is being used to make the turn while the motorcycle is leaning, so less traction is available for stopping.

questions.question: When may you not need to increase your following distance?
questions.answerB: When there is a lot of traffic
questions.answerC: When you can see through the vehicle in front of you
questions.answerD: When it is raining
questions.explanation: An increased following distance is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a longer following distance.

questions.question: If a driver is following you too closely, you should:
questions.answerA: Flash your brake light before you slow to warn the other driver.
questions.answerB: Accelerate.
questions.answerC: Pull over to the side of the road.
questions.answerD: Slow down.
questions.explanation: If someone is following you too closely, it is a good idea to flash your brake light before slowing down. A tailgater may be concentrating on you and not see upcoming hazards that require traffic to slow down.

questions.question: On a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: The front brake is more powerful than the rear brake.
questions.answerB: The rear brake is more powerful than the front brake.
questions.answerC: The emergency brake is more powerful than the front or rear brake.
questions.answerD: Brakes should only be used one at a time.
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake, providing about three-quarters of the motorcycle's total stopping power. Always use both brakes simultaneously when you slow or stop.

questions.question: If you must brake and swerve to avoid a hazard, you should:
questions.answerB: Do both at the same time.
questions.answerC: Always apply the brakes first, then swerve.
questions.answerD: Try instead to use only the brakes.
questions.explanation: If you must brake and swerve to avoid a hazard, you should perform both actions separately. Brake then swerve, or swerve then brake. Do not do both at the same time.

questions.question: A motorcycle “fits” you if:
questions.answerA: You are able to touch your feet to the ground while seated.
questions.answerB: You are able to reach the controls by stretching.
questions.answerC: The handlebars go over your head.
questions.answerD: Your feet are unable to rest on the foot pegs.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle fits you properly if your feet can reach the ground while you are seated on the motorcycle. It should be easy for you to reach and operate the controls.

questions.question: To carry a passenger, you may need to adjust all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Mirror positions.
questions.answerC: Headlight position.
questions.answerD: Brake light position.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle carrying a passenger will sit differently than usual due to the additional weight. You may need to adjust the tire pressure, suspension, shocks, headlight, and mirrors to compensate for the shift.

questions.question: Before mounting a motorcycle, you should check all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: The air pressure in the tires.
questions.answerB: Fluid levels.
questions.answerC: The turn signals.
questions.answerD: Damage to the paint.
questions.explanation: Before getting on a motorcycle, you should check the tread and air pressure of the tires, the oil and fluid levels, the lights, and the signals.

questions.question: Clothing made of which type of material can offer the best protection to motorcyclists?
questions.answerB: Wool
questions.answerC: Polyester
questions.answerD: Silk
questions.explanation: Leather garments can provide the greatest level of protection to motorcyclists. It is important to wear clothing that covers your legs and arms entirely when riding a motorcycle.

questions.question: To stop quickly, you should:
questions.answerA: Rely only on the front brake.
questions.answerB: Rely only on the rear brake.
questions.answerC: Use the front brake and then the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Use both brakes at the same time.
questions.explanation: If you need to stop quickly, you should apply both brakes at the same time.

questions.question: If either tire goes flat while riding, you should:
questions.answerB: Hold the handle grips loosely.
questions.answerC: Gently apply the brake of the non-flat tire.
questions.answerD: Increase your speed to exit the road more quickly.
questions.explanation: If one of your tires goes flat while you are riding, you should ease off the throttle and maintain a straight course as you slow down. If you must brake, gradually apply the brake of the tire that is not flat, if you are certain of which tire that is.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume the motorcycle is as easy to see as other vehicles.
questions.answerB: Assume other drivers can’t see you.
questions.answerC: Not be concerned with taking steps to ensure that other drivers see you.
questions.answerD: Ride offensively.
questions.explanation: Because motorcycles are small in stature and have fewer and smaller lights than other vehicles, they can be difficult to see. For your safety, it is best to ride defensively and assume that others on the road do not see you.

questions.question: The middle portion of the lane usually contains an oily strip. You should:
questions.answerA: Try to avoid the oily strip when it is raining.
questions.answerB: Ride only on the oily strip, as it provides increased traction.
questions.answerC: Avoid the entire center portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Not worry about oil or other items in a lane.
questions.explanation: Oily drippings from cars and trucks build up in the center of each lane. Unless the road is wet, this strip usually still provides enough traction more a motorcycle to operate safely. The strip is generally narrow enough that you can ride to either side of it and still be in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: A motorcyclist can discourage other vehicles from lane sharing by:
questions.answerA: Riding in the left portion of a lane.
questions.answerB: Riding in the center portion of a lane.
questions.answerC: Giving dirty looks if another driver moves into their lane.
questions.answerD: Riding in a zigzag pattern to fill up a lane.
questions.explanation: Any time a driver may be tempted to try to squeeze into your lane next to you, ride in the center portion of the lane to discourage them from doing so.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a factor in determining blood alcohol content (BAC)?
questions.answerB: How fast the alcohol is consumed
questions.answerC: The drinker's body weight
questions.answerD: How often the drinker consumes alcohol
questions.explanation: The three major factors that affect a person's blood alcohol content (BAC) are the amount of alcohol consumed, how fast the alcohol was consumed, and the drinker's body weight. It is illegal and dangerous to operate a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: Studies show that nearly ______ of riders killed in motorcycle crashes had been drinking.
questions.answerB: 40 percent
questions.answerC: 60 percent
questions.answerD: 80 percent
questions.explanation: Alcohol is a major contributor to motorcycle crashes, particularly fatal crashes. Studies show that nearly 40 percent of all riders killed in motorcycle accidents had been drinking.

questions.question: When preparing to pass another vehicle on the left, which portion of the lane should you ride in?
questions.answerB: The center portion
questions.answerC: The right portion
questions.answerD: The shoulder
questions.explanation: When preparing to pass another vehicle on its left, you should ride in the left portion of the lane to increase your line of sight and make yourself more visible to oncoming traffic.

questions.question: If you borrow a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Don’t worry about checking the tire pressure.
questions.answerB: Expect it to handle the same as your own bike.
questions.answerC: The lender will make sure the brakes work so you don't have to.
questions.answerD: Give yourself an extra cushion of space when riding to allow more time to react.
questions.explanation: If you borrow a motorcycle, make all of the same pre-ride safety checks that you would make on your own motorcycle. You should ride cautiously when using an unfamiliar motorcycle and allow yourself extra space when stopping.

questions.question: Which of the following does not need to be checked regularly?
questions.answerB: The fasteners
questions.answerC: The tires
questions.answerD: The paint
questions.explanation: Before every ride, you should check your motorcycle's tires, controls, chains, sprockets, shock absorbers, fasteners, and brakes. A small mechanical issue on a motorcycle can be extremely dangerous in traffic.

questions.question: Riding between two vehicles moving in the same direction:
questions.answerB: Is encouraged if traffic is heavy.
questions.answerC: Is encouraged during the day to prevent traffic jams.
questions.answerD: Is acceptable if the motorcyclist is comfortable with the move.
questions.explanation: In Oregon, it is illegal for motorcycles and mopeds to pass between two moving vehicles on a multilane highway or one-way street.

questions.question: As the motorcycle’s weight moves forward while braking, you:
questions.answerA: Can apply the front brake harder.
questions.answerB: Should lessen the amount of pressure on the front brake.
questions.answerC: Can apply the rear brake harder.
questions.answerD: Lose traction.
questions.explanation: As your weight shifts forward while you are braking, the amount of traction available to the front wheel increases. This means that you can begin to apply the front brake harder.

questions.question: The best way to handle tailgaters is to:
questions.answerA: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.answerB: Use your horn and make obscene gestures.
questions.answerC: Speed up to put distance between you and the tailgater.
questions.answerD: Come to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: If possible, change lanes and let a tailgater pass your vehicle. Speeding up may result in the driver continuing to tailgate you at a higher speed, thereby increasing the danger.

questions.question: Swerving a motorcycle:
questions.answerB: Requires little traction.
questions.answerC: Is a slow maneuver.
questions.answerD: Should be done to avoid a hazard on a slippery road.
questions.explanation: Swerving is a quick maneuver that requires a lot of traction in order to be safely executed. Making sudden moves, such as swerving, on slippery surfaces should be avoided.

questions.question: Of the following, which is not considered protective clothing?
questions.answerB: Full-fingered gloves
questions.answerC: Long pants made of denim
questions.answerD: Athletic shoes
questions.explanation: In the event of a fall, a motorcyclist can receive protection from a leather jacket, long pants made of heavy denim, and full-fingered gloves. It is best for a motorcyclist to wear lace-up boots, high-top boots, or heavy shoes that support their ankles.

questions.question: When approaching an object or uneven surface that you cannot avoid, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure the motorcycle is leaning to one side.
questions.answerB: Speed up.
questions.answerC: Swerve quickly.
questions.answerD: Rise slightly off the seat to allow your legs to absorb the shock.
questions.explanation: If you cannot avoid riding over an obstacle or uneven surface, you should approach it at as close to a 90-degree angle as possible. Slow down as much as you can, make sure that your motorcycle is upright, and rise slightly off your seat so your knees can absorb some of the force of impact. Just before contact, roll on the throttle slightly to lighten the front end.

questions.question: Before carrying a passenger in traffic for the first time, you should:
questions.answerB: Practice riding on an empty road.
questions.answerC: Flash your lights so others can see you.
questions.answerD: Practice riding on the shoulder of a road.
questions.explanation: Before transporting a passenger or heavy load in traffic for the first time, practice riding on a quiet road to get used to how your motorcycle handles differently with the additional weight.

questions.question: A DOT-compliant helmet has all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: An impact-absorbing inner liner.
questions.answerC: A chinstrap retention system.
questions.answerD: Bright colors painted on the outside.
questions.explanation: Any U.S. Department of Transportation-compliant helmet is required to have an impact-resistant outer shell, an impact-absorbing inner liner, a comfort liner, and a chinstrap retention system.

questions.question: The control for the rear brake is usually located:
questions.answerB: On the left handlebar.
questions.answerC: Near the left foot.
questions.answerD: Near the right foot.
questions.explanation: The rear brake of a motorcycle is usually operated with the right foot.

questions.question: When riding in a lane of traffic, a motorcycle operator:
questions.answerA: Should always ride in the same part of the lane.
questions.answerB: Should vary their lane position according to riding conditions.
questions.answerC: Should always ride in the center of the lane.
questions.answerD: Should always ride in the left part of the lane.
questions.explanation: There is no single lane position that is always best and no single lane position that should always be avoided. Vary your lane position based on changing road and traffic conditions.

questions.question: Use a turn signal:
questions.answerA: When you’re planning to increase your speed.
questions.answerB: Only when there is a lot of traffic.
questions.answerC: Any time you plan on changing lanes.
questions.answerD: Only if it is dark outside.
questions.explanation: You should use a turn signal every time you plan to turn or change lanes, even if you think no one else is around to see it.

questions.question: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should ride:
questions.answerA: In the front of the group.
questions.answerB: Right behind the leader.
questions.answerC: At the back of the group.
questions.answerD: Wherever they are most comfortable.
questions.explanation: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should ride just behind the leader near the front of the group. This allows more experienced riders to keep an eye on them from the back of the group.

questions.question: When riding, the best sitting position:
questions.answerA: Requires your arms be used to hold you up.
questions.answerB: Allows you to easily reach the controls.
questions.answerC: Keeps your arms straight when reaching the handle grips.
questions.answerD: Keeps your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.explanation: When riding, you should be seated in a posture that allows you to use your arms to steer rather than to hold yourself up. You should not have to stretch to reach the handgrips and your arms should be slightly bent when holding them. You should keep your knees against the gas tank to maintain your balance.

questions.question: When looking for a protective jacket or pair of pants, you should look for:
questions.answerB: Items made of polyester.
questions.answerC: Items made of light materials.
questions.answerD: Items that are darkly-colored.
questions.explanation: It is safest to wear long pants and a jacket to fully cover your arms and legs while riding. Clothing made of leather can provide the highest level of protection.

questions.question: Mirror checks:
questions.answerA: Should be part of your normal scanning routine.
questions.answerB: Should be avoided because they will distract you.
questions.answerC: Should be avoided since other drivers will see you easily.
questions.answerD: Are only recommended in bad weather.
questions.explanation: For your safety, it is important to be aware of what's behind you. Frequent mirror checks should be a part of your normal searching routine.

questions.question: To control a motorcycle properly, you should:
questions.answerA: Sit so you can use your arms to steer, not to hold yourself up.
questions.answerB: Sit far enough back on the seat that you can keep your arms straight.
questions.answerC: Keep your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerD: Drag your feet on the ground.
questions.explanation: When riding, sit so you are able use your arms to control the motorcycle rather than to hold yourself up. Your arms should be slightly bent when you are holding the handle grips. To help maintain your balance, keep your knees against the gas tank and your feet firmly on the footrests.

questions.question: When braking where traction is reduced, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes more quickly than usual.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes more gently than usual.
questions.answerC: Not use the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Not use the front brake.
questions.explanation: When slowing or stopping on a surface with reduced traction, you should use caution and apply the brakes more gently than usual.

questions.question: Which of the following types of footwear is best for a motorcycle operator?
questions.answerB: Tennis shoes
questions.answerC: Shoes with loose laces
questions.answerD: Sandals
questions.explanation: Sturdy boots or shoes that are high enough to support the ankles can provide the best protection for motorcyclists. Laced up boots are best, but high-top boots or heavy shoes are fine. If a motorcyclist wears shoes that have long laces, they should be sure to securely tuck the laces away before riding.

questions.question: A motorcycle operator can slow down by:
questions.answerB: Upshfting.
questions.answerC: Cross-shifting.
questions.answerD: Rolling on the throttle.
questions.explanation: Motorcyclists often slow down by simply downshifting. Motorcyclists should be aware that slowing down in this manner does not activate the brake lights.

questions.question: Normally, you should maintain a following distance of:
questions.answerB: Two seconds.
questions.answerC: Three seconds.
questions.answerD: Four seconds.
questions.explanation: Under normal conditions, you should allow at least two seconds of distance between you and the vehicle ahead of you. Increase your following distance any time conditions are less than ideal.

questions.question: Your primary source for information about your motorcycle should be:
questions.answerB: A book about motorcycles.
questions.answerC: A former owner.
questions.answerD: Someone knowledgeable about motorcycles.
questions.explanation: Your owner's manual should be your primary source for information about your specific motorcycle. Your manual will include information about the motorcycle's specifications, operation, and suggested maintenance.

questions.question: Riding at night:
questions.answerB: Is made safer by wearing reflective clothing.
questions.answerC: Is not safe because other drivers cannot see your turn signals.
questions.answerD: Should only be done in the city.
questions.explanation: You should wear reflective materials when riding at night to make yourself more visible to other road users.

questions.question: Which vest or jacket color would best help you to be seen?
questions.answerB: Black
questions.answerC: Silver
questions.answerD: Blue
questions.explanation: Wearing brightly-colored clothing while riding will increase your chances of being seen. Bright oranges, yellows, reds, or greens are best and are preferable to drab or dark colors.

questions.question: If riding with a passenger, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Adjust your motorcycle to accommodate the rider.
questions.answerB: Instruct the passenger before you start riding.
questions.answerC: Tell the passenger to keep their feet firmly on the footrests.
questions.answerD: Try to squeeze onto a one-person seat.
questions.explanation: You cannot carry a passenger unless your motorcycle is equipped with a permanent passenger seat and footrests. Provide instructions to the passenger before starting out.

questions.question: If hazards are on your left, you should ride:
questions.answerA: In the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: In the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: In any portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: On the shoulder.
questions.explanation: When hazards exist to your left, it is often best to ride in the right portion of the lane. Be prepared to adjust your lane position as road and traffic conditions change.

questions.question: You can increase your visibility by:
questions.answerA: Adding auxiliary lights to your motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Not using your turn signal.
questions.answerC: Wearing dark clothing.
questions.answerD: Waving at people.
questions.explanation: To increase your visibility, you can wear clothing that is brightly-colored or that contains reflective materials. Adding auxiliary lights to your motorcycle, using your turn signals, and flashing your brake light when appropriate are also good ways to get the attention of other road users.

questions.question: When someone is following you too closely, you should:
questions.answerB: Slow down and let them pass.
questions.answerC: Move onto the shoulder and stop.
questions.answerD: Not be concerned.
questions.explanation: The best way to handle a tailgater is to get them in front of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let them pass. Speeding up may only increase the danger by causing them to continue tailgating you at the higher speed.

questions.question: When riding in a group, the best riding formation is generally:
questions.answerB: A staggered formation.
questions.answerC: A single-file line.
questions.answerD: A pyramid formation.
questions.explanation: A staggered formation is generally best when riding in a group. You should move into a single-file line when turning, riding in a curve, or entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: To stop quickly, you should:
questions.answerB: Use only the front brake.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes.
questions.answerD: Use the rear brake firmly while gradually increasing the braking pressure of the front brake.
questions.explanation: To stop quickly, apply both brakes at the same time.

questions.question: When braking:
questions.answerA: Use only one brake if it is a non-emergency situation.
questions.answerB: Only use both brakes if you are riding on wet pavement.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes regardless of the circumstances.
questions.answerD: Use only the front brake.
questions.explanation: You should use both brakes every time you slow or stop.

questions.question: Smoothly downshifting on motorcycles:
questions.answerB: Can allow the rider to engine brake.
questions.answerC: Is illegal.
questions.answerD: Should not be done if other vehicles are around.
questions.explanation: Engine braking by smoothly downshifting can be a useful option for motorcyclists. If you choose to engine brake, apply your brake lights separately to let other drivers know that you are slowing down.

questions.question: When you are riding on a bridge grating, you should:
questions.answerA: Always ride on the far right side of the lane.
questions.answerB: Always ride on the far left side of the lane.
questions.answerC: Slowly zigzag across the grating.
questions.answerD: Relax, maintain a steady speed, and ride straight across the surface.
questions.explanation: Crossing rain grooves or bridge gratings may cause your motorcycle to move in a weaving motion. This is usually not dangerous, so simply relax and proceed across the surface at a steady speed. Trying to ride at an angle to compensate for the weave is dangerous because it forces you to zigzag to stay in your lane.

questions.question: Where should a load be placed?
questions.answerB: As high as possible
questions.answerC: Behind the rear axle
questions.answerD: On one side of the motorcycle
questions.explanation: Loads should kept low, either fastened securely or in saddlebags. Piling loads against a sissy bar or frame on the back of a seat is dangerous because it can raise the motorcycle's center of gravity and change the balance of the motorcycle. Loads should be equally distributed on both sides of the motorcycle.

questions.question: On which of the following surfaces does a motorcycle have the best traction?
questions.answerB: Gravel
questions.answerC: Snow
questions.answerD: Leaves
questions.explanation: A number of surfaces can provide poor traction for tires. Wet pavement; roads covered in loose gravel or sand; muddy, snowy, or icy areas; painted lane markings; and metal covers and plates in the road can be more hazardous for a motorcyclist than dry pavement.

questions.question: A windshield:
questions.answerA: Is a good substitute for a face shield.
questions.answerB: Does not completely protect your eyes from the wind.
questions.answerC: Is required on all motorcycles.
questions.answerD: Should be used on windy days.
questions.explanation: A windshield is not an adequate substitute for the protection offered by goggles or a face shield. Most windshields will not protect your eyes from the wind.

questions.question: If your rear wheel locks while braking, you should:
questions.answerA: Release the brake until the rear tire regains traction, then re-apply the brake.
questions.answerB: Release the brake and only engage the front brake.
questions.answerC: Keep it locked until the motorcycle comes to a stop.
questions.answerD: Release the brake and coast to a stop.
questions.explanation: If your rear wheel locks while braking, do not release the brake. Instead, keep it locked until you come to a full stop.

questions.question: What is the primary psychoactive component in marijuana?
questions.answerB: TMJ
questions.answerC: MRT
questions.answerD: AAP
questions.explanation: The main psychoactive substance in marijuana is called tetrahydrocannabinol, or THC.

questions.question: When being passed, all of the following are potential hazards, except:
questions.answerB: Objects being thrown from other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Blasts of wind.
questions.answerD: Headlights.
questions.explanation: When being passed, motorcyclists should be careful not to be hit by any part of the passing vehicle, including its mirrors. In addition to the vehicle itself, motorcyclists should be aware of wind gusts coming from the passing vehicle and potential objects being thrown by a passenger in the vehicle who may not be paying attention to the road.

questions.question: Brightly-colored helmets:
questions.answerA: May make it easier for the wearer to be seen.
questions.answerB: Can be distracting.
questions.answerC: Don’t help to improve a rider's visibility.
questions.answerD: Are not permitted.
questions.explanation: Choosing a brightly-colored helmet is recommended. Not only will the helmet protect you in the case of a crash, but the bright color of the helmet will help other road users see you.

questions.question: If your front wheel skids as a result of braking, you should:
questions.answerB: Release the front brake immediately and re-apply the brake smoothly.
questions.answerC: Release the front brake and only use the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Release both brakes and coast to a stop.
questions.explanation: If your front wheel locks as a result of braking, you should release the front brake immediately and re-apply the brake smoothly.

questions.question: When being followed too closely by another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerB: Move onto the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Allow the other driver to pass you.
questions.answerD: Exit the roadway.
questions.explanation: The best way to deal with a tailgater is to get them ahead of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let them pass. Speeding up may only increase the danger by encouraging them to continue tailgating you at a higher speed.

questions.question: When you ride, the best gear to wear is:
questions.answerA: Any gear that helps to protect you.
questions.answerB: The lowest-priced gear.
questions.answerC: Gear that looks good.
questions.answerD: Any gear that fits.
questions.explanation: You should wear gear that helps protect you while you ride. It is best to wear a DOT-approved helmet, face or eye protection, and protective clothing.

questions.question: A proper lane position can help you do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Increase your ability to see and be seen.
questions.answerC: Go faster.
questions.answerD: Set up for turns.
questions.explanation: Your lane position affects a number of factors that are important to your safety on the road. Among other things, your position should help you increase your ability to see and be seen, avoid other drivers' blind spots, and set you up for any turns you plan to make.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of protective riding gear?
questions.answerB: Boots that go above the ankle
questions.answerC: Hearing protection
questions.answerD: Pants made of a soft material
questions.explanation: Appropriate protective gear for motorcycling includes a jacket and pants made of leather or another sturdy material; footwear that covers and supports your ankles; and hearing protection, even if you wear a helmet.

questions.question: Maintaining a cushion of space allows you:
questions.answerA: Space to maneuver if another driver makes a mistake.
questions.answerB: To turn more quickly.
questions.answerC: To not react to other drivers.
questions.answerD: To ride more slowly.
questions.explanation: Maintaining a space cushion helps ensure that you will have time to react and maneuver if another driver makes a mistake.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle and trying to turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Press the grip in the direction you want to turn.
questions.answerB: Press the grip opposite of the direction you want to turn.
questions.answerC: Not hold the grip because it can be dangerous.
questions.answerD: Not lean the motorcycle as that can be unsafe.
questions.explanation: When traveling faster than a walking pace, your motorcycle will need to lean to turn. Pressing the grip in the direction you want to turn will cause you to lean in the appropriate direction

questions.question: When riding in a group, it is best to put inexperienced riders near the front because:
questions.answerA: Experienced riders can more easily keep an eye on them.
questions.answerB: They will get lost if they are leading.
questions.answerC: They may slow the group down as the leaders.
questions.answerD: They will ride too fast in any other position.
questions.explanation: In a group, less experienced riders should ride toward the front, just behind the leader, so more experienced riders can easily watch them.

questions.question: After drinking, what lessens the effects of alcohol?
questions.answerB: Coffee
questions.answerC: Time
questions.answerD: Food
questions.explanation: The liver burns alcohol at a set rate, and there is nothing you can do to speed along the process. The only way to lessen the effects of alcohol is to give your body the time needed to remove it.

questions.question: When loading cargo onto a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Pack heavier items in front of the tank bag.
questions.answerB: Pack lighter items near the front.
questions.answerC: Try to not place items over the rear axle.
questions.answerD: Place items behind the rear axle.
questions.explanation: Heavier items should be loaded in front of the tank bag. You should try to place the load over or in front of the rear axle. Putting the load behind the rear axle may affect your control.

questions.question: The best lane position:
questions.answerA: Is always the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Is always the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Is always the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Varies based on road, weather, and traffic conditions.
questions.explanation: There is no single lane position that is always best and no single lane position that should always be avoided. You should vary your lane position in response to changes in riding conditions.

questions.question: The idea that a motorcycle helmet limits a wearer's views to each side:
questions.answerA: Is accurate. Views are limited and can cause a hazard.
questions.answerB: Is accurate, but only in that views are limited on sunny days.
questions.answerC: Is accurate. Views are limited horizontally.
questions.answerD: Is inaccurate. Views are not limited.
questions.explanation: An approved motorcycle helmet will allow the wearer to see as far to the sides as is necessary for safe riding.

questions.question: Riding with a passenger:
questions.answerA: Usually results in no difference in handling a motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Is usually safe for beginning riders.
questions.answerC: Can affect the handling of a motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Is encouraged to get operators used to different riding situations.
questions.explanation: A passenger puts extra weight on a motorcycle, which causes the motorcycle to handle differently. Only experienced riders should carry passengers.

questions.question: When going through a curve, you should:
questions.answerA: Always stay in the same portion of the lane throughout the entire curve.
questions.answerB: Always stay in the left portion of the lane throughout the entire curve.
questions.answerC: Always stay in the right portion of the lane throughout the entire curve.
questions.answerD: Remember that the best path may not follow the curve of the road.
questions.explanation: Road and traffic conditions can change at any time. Always be prepared to change your lane position as appropriate no matter where you are on a roadway. The best path through a curve does not necessarily follow the curve of the road.

questions.question: On a slippery surface, you should not:
questions.answerB: Avoid making sudden moves.
questions.answerC: Use only the front brake when slowing or stopping.
questions.answerD: Use both brakes when slowing or stopping.
questions.explanation: To ride safely on a slippery surface, you should use both brakes when slowing or stopping, reduce your speed, and avoid making sudden moves. Be alert to oily areas, dirt, gravel, shaded areas, and bridges, as these surfaces are more likely to be slippery than others.

questions.question: Motorists entering a highway from an entrance ramp to your right may not see your motorcycle. To help the entering drivers, you should:
questions.answerB: Flash your lights.
questions.answerC: Move to the left portion of your lane so they can share the lane, if necessary.
questions.answerD: Move into another lane, if necessary.
questions.explanation: Give plenty of room to vehicles merging onto a highway from an entrance ramp. Merge into a lane farther away from the entrance ramp, if necessary. If it is not possible to change lanes, adjust your speed to allow room for the vehicle to safely enter the highway.

questions.question: When riding with a heavy load, you will want to adjust the:
questions.answerB: Seat.
questions.answerC: Suspension.
questions.answerD: Brake light.
questions.explanation: Before riding with a heavy load, you should make sure your tire pressure, spring pre-load, air shocks, and dampers are at the settings recommended for the relevant weight.

questions.question: Taking corners too fast:
questions.answerA: Can cause the rider to go into another lane.
questions.answerB: Is better than going too slowly.
questions.answerC: Often causes the rider to stay in their lane.
questions.answerD: Is acceptable because motorcycles are smaller than other types of vehicles.
questions.explanation: Taking a corner too fast may cause you to cross into another lane or go off the road. Be sure to decelerate before beginning to take a turn or curve.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of an accident, you should:
questions.answerB: Follow the vehicle in front of you as closely as possible.
questions.answerC: Not look ahead and focus only on your controls.
questions.answerD: Communicate your intentions to other drivers.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle.

questions.question: ______ is a guarantee that another driver sees you.
questions.answerB: Using a turn signal
questions.answerC: Following another vehicle
questions.answerD: Nothing
questions.explanation: Nothing guarantees that a driver sees you. It is safest to assume that if another vehicle can enter your path, it will.

questions.question: Which of the following is not considered protective clothing for a motorcyclist?
questions.answerB: Boots
questions.answerC: Gloves
questions.answerD: A stocking cap
questions.explanation: You should wear appropriate protective clothing when riding. Protective garments include sturdy pants and jackets that entirely cover your arms and legs, boots or heavy shoes that cover and support your ankles, and sturdy gloves.

questions.question: When making an ordinary stop, you should:
questions.answerA: Use both the front and rear brakes.
questions.answerB: Use only the rear brake to save the front brake for special situations.
questions.answerC: Use only the front brake to save the rear brake for special situations.
questions.answerD: Sharply squeeze the front brake only.
questions.explanation: Develop the habit of using both brakes every time you slow or stop. If you need to stop quickly, it is best to apply both brakes. It will be easier to apply both brakes in a quick stop if you have already developed this habit.

questions.question: Which of the following provides the best protection?
questions.answerB: Windshield
questions.answerC: Goggles
questions.answerD: Face shield
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield provides protection for the wearer's entire face in the event of a crash. Goggles may protect someone's eyes, but not the rest of their face. A windshield is not an adequate substitute for either.

questions.question: If you are riding and your motorcycle starts to handle differently, you should:
questions.answerB: Pull over and check the tires.
questions.answerC: Pull over to check the chain.
questions.answerD: Pull over to check the windshield.
questions.explanation: A sudden change in handling may indicate that a tire on your motorcycle has failed. If you feel a change in the way your motorcycle handles, pull over safely and check your tires.

questions.question: When braking on a slippery surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Use both the front and rear brakes.
questions.answerB: Use abrupt pressure on the front brake to prevent locking the front tire.
questions.answerC: Only use the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Use either brake, but use only one brake.
questions.explanation: When riding on slippery surfaces, you should use both brakes to slow down. Squeeze the brake lever gradually to avoid locking the front wheel and use gentle pressure on the rear brake.

questions.question: Of the following, which gear will not help to properly protect a motorcyclist?
questions.answerB: A face shield
questions.answerC: Clothing made of sturdy material
questions.answerD: A baseball cap
questions.explanation: To protect yourself while riding, you should wear an approved helmet, face or eye protection, and protective clothing.

questions.question: When riding at night, you should:
questions.answerB: Increase your following distance.
questions.answerC: Ride faster than you usually would.
questions.answerD: Avoid using your high beam headlight.
questions.explanation: Because distances are more difficult to judge in the dark than in daylight, be sure to reduce your speed and increase your following distance when riding at night. Use your high beam any time you are not meeting or following another vehicle.

questions.question: Where is the gearshift lever located?
questions.answerA: In front of the left footrest
questions.answerB: In front of the right footrest
questions.answerC: On the left handgrip
questions.answerD: On the right handgrip
questions.explanation: The gearshift lever is located in front of the left footrest and is operated with the left foot.

questions.question: Riding gloves are often:
questions.answerB: Made of wool.
questions.answerC: Not pre-curved.
questions.answerD: Unsafe for the rider.
questions.explanation: Gloves designed for motorcycle riding are usually made of leather. In addition to improving your grip, gloves provide protection for a rider's hands and fingers.

questions.question: Use your mirrors when stopped at an intersection:
questions.answerA: To see if vehicles parked on the sides of the street are entering traffic.
questions.answerB: To look for vehicles changing lanes.
questions.answerC: To watch for vehicles behind you that may not be slowing down.
questions.answerD: To see if someone is planning to turn behind you.
questions.explanation: When you are stopped at an intersection, use your mirrors to check for cars approaching you from behind. The drivers may not notice you until they are too close and you may need to react.

questions.question: What may help if you experience slippage of your drive chain?
questions.answerB: Loosening the chain
questions.answerC: Using the throttle more
questions.answerD: Applying the rear brake
questions.explanation: If you experience chain slippage, tightening the chain may help. If tightening the chain does not reverse the problem, replace the chain before continuing to ride your motorcycle.

questions.question: When you have mounted your motorcycle, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Make sure the mirrors are clean.
questions.answerB: Make sure the horn works.
questions.answerC: Close the fuel supply valve.
questions.answerD: Make sure the clutch works smoothly.
questions.explanation: After mounting your motorcycle, you should make sure the clutch, throttle, horn, and brakes all work properly. Clean and adjust the mirrors and make sure that the fuel supply valve is open.

questions.question: If a tire goes flat and you must brake, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brake of the tire that is not flat.
questions.answerB: Apply the brake of the tire that is flat.
questions.answerC: Apply both brakes.
questions.answerD: Not use either brake.
questions.explanation: If either of your tires go flat and you must brake, gradually apply the brake of the tire that is not flat (if you are certain of which tire that is).

questions.question: A major effect of alcohol consumption is:
questions.answerB: The slowing down of bodily functions.
questions.answerC: Increasing nervousness.
questions.answerD: Increasing alertness.
questions.explanation: Alcohol is a depressant. It slows down and impairs bodily functions, both physical and mental.

questions.question: Fatigue can be increased by:
questions.answerB: Riding in cool weather.
questions.answerC: Being comfortable during your ride.
questions.answerD: Starting a ride late in the day.
questions.explanation: To reduce the danger of fatigue when riding, dress to protect yourself against tiring weather conditions, such as wind and rain. Limit yourself to no more than about six hours of riding per day and stop for a break at least once every two hours. Avoid taking artificial stimulants since you may experience extreme fatigue when they start to wear off.

questions.question: You will ______ hear a tire going flat.
questions.answerB: Usually
questions.answerC: Frequently
questions.answerD: Seldom
questions.explanation: Motorcyclists will seldom hear their tire go flat. Tire failure is more commonly indicated by a sudden change in handling.

questions.question: You should completely check your motorcycle:
questions.answerB: Once a week.
questions.answerC: Once a month.
questions.answerD: Once a year.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle requires more frequent attention than a car. Make a complete check of your motorcycle before every ride.

questions.question: Drivers on an entrance ramp may not see you on the highway. What should you do to help an entering driver merge safely?
questions.answerA: Stay in your lane, as it is not your responsibility to be seen.
questions.answerB: Change to a lane away from the entrance ramp, if possible.
questions.answerC: Move to the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Weave within your lane to be more obvious to the entering driver.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a collision, always allow merging vehicles plenty of space to safely enter traffic. Change lanes away from the entrance ramp if there is room to do so safely. If there isn't another lane available, adjust your speed to open up space for the merging driver.

questions.question: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should position themselves:
questions.answerB: In front of the group.
questions.answerC: At the tail end of the group.
questions.answerD: Beside the leader.
questions.explanation: In a group of motorcyclists, riders with less experience should be positioned toward the front of the group, just behind the leader. This will allow more experienced riders to keep an eye on them without forcing the inexperienced rider to lead the group.

questions.question: What does this signal mean?
questions.answerB: High beams on
questions.answerC: Turn right
questions.answerD: Hazard
questions.explanation: Signals are an important part of communication when riding in groups. When the lead rider's right leg is extended, it means there is a hazard in the roadway on their right side.

questions.question: A helmeted rider is _______ more likely to survive a crash than a rider not wearing a helmet.
questions.answerB: Three times
questions.answerC: Six times
questions.answerD: 20 times
questions.explanation: No matter the speed, riders who are not wearing helmets are three times more likely to die from head injuries than riders who are wearing helmets at the time of a crash.

questions.question: Generally, the body eliminates one alcoholic drink per hour. If a person consumed eight alcoholic drinks four hours ago, how many drinks likely remain in their body?
questions.answerB: Two drinks
questions.answerC: Three drinks
questions.answerD: Four drinks
questions.explanation: The minimum number of drinks left in a person's system can be estimated by subtracting the number of hours since the last drink from the total number of drinks consumed. In this case, the alcohol content of about four drinks would remain.

questions.question: To get the best possible protection, wear a helmet that:
questions.answerB: Is well-worn and broken in.
questions.answerC: Is pretty loose.
questions.answerD: Does not have a chinstrap.
questions.explanation: Choose a helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and state standards. It should fit you snugly all the way around and be free of obvious defects.

questions.question: It is a good idea to wear reflective clothing:
questions.answerB: During the day.
questions.answerC: At dusk.
questions.answerD: All of the above.
questions.explanation: Wearing reflective and brightly-colored clothing is always a good idea when riding a motorcycle. Crashes occur in broad daylight and at night, so it is best to wear highly visible clothing at any time of day.

questions.question: If you are feeling tired while riding, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep going and hope to wake up.
questions.answerB: Ride faster.
questions.answerC: Ride on the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Get off the road and rest.
questions.explanation: You should avoid riding if you are tired. When making a long trip, take rest breaks at least every two hours to reduce the risk of becoming fatigued.

questions.question: When you park a motorcycle next to a curb, it should be:
questions.answerA: Parked at a 90-degree angle with the rear wheel touching the curb.
questions.answerB: Parked at a 45-degree angle with the front tire touching the curb.
questions.answerC: Parked like a car, with the front and rear wheels the same distance from the curb.
questions.answerD: Parked at the left edge of the parking space so approaching drivers can more easily see the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: When parking a motorcycle next to a curb, you should create at a 90-degree angle with the curb by touching your rear wheel to the curb.

questions.question: Riding alongside another rider:
questions.answerA: Allows you to maximize the surface of the road.
questions.answerB: Should be avoided because it limits your escape routes.
questions.answerC: Allows you to communicate with one another.
questions.answerD: Makes it easier for other motorists to pass.
questions.explanation: You should not ride alongside another motorcyclist because doing so will limit both of your possible routes of escape if you encounter a hazard.

questions.question: The front brake supplies how much of a motorcycle's potential stopping power?
questions.answerB: About 50 percent
questions.answerC: About 70 percent
questions.answerD: 100 percent
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake and can provide at least 70 percent of the motorcycle's total stopping power.

questions.question: If you are not traveling slowly enough when shifting into a lower gear, the:
questions.answerA: Motorcycle could lurch and the rear tire could skid.
questions.answerB: Motorcycle could accelerate too quickly.
questions.answerC: Front tire will likely skid.
questions.answerD: Engine will make a loud noise.
questions.explanation: If you are not riding slowly enough when shifting into a lower gear, the motorcycle will lurch and the rear wheel may skid.

questions.question: To effectively provide protection for a motorcycle rider, pants should:
questions.answerA: Be made of a soft material.
questions.answerB: Be made of a heavy material.
questions.answerC: Fit loosely enough that they flap in the wind.
questions.answerD: Be short and expose some parts of the legs.
questions.explanation: For your protection, you should wear pants that cover your entire legs and are made of leather or another sturdy synthetic material. Clothing should fit snugly enough that it does not flap in the wind but not so snugly that it restricts your movement.

questions.question: When exiting a highway while riding in a group, which riding formation should be used?
questions.answerB: Single-file
questions.answerC: Paired up
questions.answerD: Riding three across a lane
questions.explanation: While a staggered formation is usually best for group riding, a group should switch into a single-file formation when taking curves, turning, or entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: To get the best protection, be sure that your helmet:
questions.answerB: Looks sturdy.
questions.answerC: Is inexpensive.
questions.answerD: Is in your favorite color.
questions.explanation: Choose a helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and state standards. It should fit you snugly all the way around and be free of obvious defects.

questions.question: If you are riding when it starts to rain, it is a good idea to:
questions.answerA: Ride down the center of the lane.
questions.answerB: Increase your speed.
questions.answerC: Ride in the tire tracks left by cars.
questions.answerD: Pull onto the shoulder of the road.
questions.explanation: Because of the presence of oil deposits, the center strip of a lane can be hazardous when wet. When rain starts to fall, it is best to ride in the tire tracks left by cars. It is advisable to reduce your speed on wet surfaces.

questions.question: In general, the body gets rid of almost ______ per hour.
questions.answerB: Two drinks
questions.answerC: Three drinks
questions.answerD: Four drinks
questions.explanation: On average, a person's body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour.

questions.question: How does the stopping distance for motorcycles compare to the stopping distance for cars?
questions.answerA: Cars need much longer to stop.
questions.answerB: Cars need a little longer to stop.
questions.answerC: Motorcycles need longer to stop.
questions.answerD: Both motorcycles and cars take about the same amount of time to stop.
questions.explanation: Under normal conditions, the stopping distances for motorcycles is nearly the same as it is for cars. However, slippery pavement makes quick stops especially difficult for motorcycle operators.

questions.question: When riding a three-wheeled motorcycle through a curve, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Stay in the center of the lane.
questions.answerB: Stay on the outside of the lane.
questions.answerC: Change your path as needed.
questions.answerD: Use the shoulder.
questions.explanation: The cornering characteristics of a three-wheeled motorcycle or a motorcycle with a sidecar differ from those of a two-wheeled motorcycle. The best path for a three-wheeler to take through a curve may not actually follow the curve. For example, you may need to move from the outside of the curve to the inside of the curve before straightening out your path.

questions.question: When riding at night:
questions.answerA: Distances are easier to judge than they are during the day.
questions.answerB: Using a high beam headlight always makes it difficult to see.
questions.answerC: Use only one lane position.
questions.answerD: Reduce your speed.
questions.explanation: When riding at night, you should reduce your speed and increase your following distance. Use your high beam headlight whenever you are riding where there is no other traffic. Always be prepared to adjust your lane position to react to changing conditions.

questions.question: Passengers should:
questions.answerB: Hold onto their seat.
questions.answerC: Sit as far back on the bike as possible.
questions.answerD: Never hold onto the operator.
questions.explanation: Passengers should sit directly behind the operator and lean as the operator leans. They should sit as far forward as they can without crowding the operator, holding onto the operator's waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: The front brake:
questions.answerA: Should only be used when you need to stop quickly.
questions.answerB: Should be used only under slippery conditions.
questions.answerC: Is not as effective as the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Is safe to use, if used properly.
questions.explanation: Always use both brakes any time you slow or stop. It is safe to use the front brake, which is more powerful than the rear brake, as long as you use it properly.

questions.question: When both braking and swerving must be done to avoid an unexpected hazard, a rider should:
questions.answerA: Perform one action, then the other.
questions.answerB: Perform both actions at the same time and apply extra braking pressure.
questions.answerC: Perform both actions at the same time, but mainly focus on swerving.
questions.answerD: Not perform either action.
questions.explanation: Because you need adequate traction to swerve safely, you should not brake and swerve at the same time. Instead, if you approach a hazard that requires you to brake and swerve, you should perform one action and then the other.

questions.question: When passing a vehicle:
questions.answerA: You may exceed the speed limit until the pass is complete.
questions.answerB: You may disregard "No passing zone" markings if the pass was started in a passing zone.
questions.answerC: You may pass on the shoulder.
